results.title: De Mayerling a Sarajevo = from Mayerling to Sarajevo
results.brief_description:
Ophuls traces the fall of the Austro-Hungarian empire by spiritually linking the tragic 19th century romance of Crown Duke Rudolph and Baroness Maria Vetsera to the 1914 assassination of Archduke Ferdinand and the subsequent outbreak of WWI. Mistrusted by his aristocratic peers because of his progressively democratic notions, Ferdinand seems destined to be martyred at the hands of his enemies, in much the same way that Rudolph was.

Credits: Producer, Eugene Tucherer ; director, Max Ophuls ; writers, Marcelle Maurette, Carl Zuckmayer, Jacques Natanson, Andre-Paul Antoine ; photography, Curt Alexandre, Curt Courant, Otto Heller ; music, Oscar Straus ; art direction, Jean d’Eaubonn
Cast: Edwige Feuillere, Gabrielle Doziat, John Lodge, Jacqueline Marsan, Aime Clariond, Monique Clariond, Jean Worms, Colette Regis, Jean Debucourt, Raymond Aimos, Henri Bosc.

results.title: Nous les Jericho = Sacre Grand-Pere = Dear Old Grandpa
results.brief_description:
Jericho is a retired veterinarian who lives on a property in Provence. He invites his grandson and his wife to spend the holidays. Although Marie and Jacques are about to divorce, they agree to disguise it in order to spare Jericho’s feelings. Jericho knows better, and realising that the couple is estranged, slyly works to bring about a reconciliation.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Laurent ; director, Jacques Poitrenaud ; writers, Jacques Poitrenaud, Albert Cossery, Maria Suire ; photography, Jean-Marc Ripert ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Michel Simon, Marie Dubois, Thalie Fruges, Serge Gainsbourg, Jeanne Helia, Yves Lefebvre, Mary Marquet.

results.title: Un Dimanche a la Campagne = A Sunday in the Country
results.brief_description:
In 1912, Monsieur Ladmiral, 76, lives alone in his home on the outskirts of Paris. He is a talented painter who will not adapt to the new Impressionist style. As happens most Sundays, he awaits the visit of his son and family. It promises to be a Sunday like many others, full of politeness and affection. The sudden arrival of Irene, Mr. Ladmiral’s daughter disrupts the monotony of the day. Young and emancipated, Irene stirs up the laughter of the children, the anger of Mr. Ladmiral’s son and the old man’s nostalgia. The film contains many references to French painters such as Bonnard and Vuillard, as well as to Jean Renoir’s ‘Une Partie de Campagne’. Awards: Cannes Film Festival 1984: Best mise-en-scene; French Academy of Cinema (Cesar) 1984: Best Actress Sabine Azema, Best Cinematography Bruno de Keyzer, Best Screenplay Adaptation Colo Tavernier O’Hagan and Bertrand Tavernier; New-York Film Critics Circle Award: Best Foreign Language Film.

Credits: Producers, Alain Sarde, Bertrand Tavernier ; director, Bertrand Tavernier; writers, Betrand Tavernier, Colo Tavernier O’Hagan ; photography, Bruno de Keyzer ; music, Louis Ducreux, Marc Perronne, Gabriel Faure ; costume design, Yvonne Sassino
Cast: Louis Ducreux, Sabine Azema, Michel Aumont, Genevieve Mnich, Monique Chaumette.

results.title: Touchez Pas Au Grisbi = Don't Touch the Loot
results.creator_credit: Jacques Becker, Leon Carre and Robert Dorfmann
results.brief_description:
Max and Riton have just executed a mighty heist and hidden the loot (grisbi) while things cool down. The heist was Max’s last coup before retirement. But Riton can’t help talking to his girlfriend, Josy. Josy is the talkative kind and passes the information to Angelo, a drug dealer. Angelo kidnaps Riton in order to make him reveal the location of the loot. Max must set aside his dreams of cosy retirement and respectability to retrieve his friend and the loot from Angelo’s grasp. It’s a kind of an older guys/young chicks picture with a pair of middle-aged men (Jean Gabin, Rene Darcy) dining at the same Montmartre cafe every night and heading for a nightclub where their girlfriends (Dora Doll, Jeanne Moreau) dance in the chorus. Gabin has reached the age where he’d like to have called it a night lots earlier if he didn’t have an image to maintain, but Darcy still likes to play around. Gabin’s girl (Doll) is an uncomplicated blond—the actress’ name fits the character she’s playing to perfection—but Moreau, not surprisingly, is not just another cutie with bangs and a ponytail. She’s got an eye on the main chance, and Darcy’s pillow talk has netted her the prize information that Gabin is sitting on a fortune in stolen gold bricks. When Gabin’s erstwhile comrade (Lino Ventura) hears this news, the plot of the film, adapted from an Albert Simonin serie noire novel, kicks in. What concerns Becker is that eternal theme, the question of honor among thieves. Gabin is suddenly thrust into a dangerous, volatile predicament, but his loyalty to the foolish Darcy never flags. ‘Grisbi’ is loaded with night-life atmosphere, and it offers the unique opportunity to see together France’s greatest screen icon, Gabin, the virile man of the people, with Moreau and Ventura, who were to become icons themselves. Indeed, Ventura (in his screen debut), whom Becker discovered in a wrestling ring, would eventually succeed Gabin as France’s definitive, world-weary tough guy. There are a couple of moments when Moreau, who would become the grande dame of the French cinema, has an uncanny Brigitte Bardot look, but already she projected a hauteur to be reckoned with.” Reference: Kevin Thomas. ‘Cinema dangereuse’. Hollywood Online, 18/6/98. Online. http://www.hollywood.com/news/topstories/06-18-98/html/1-3.html Further reference: Cinematheque Ontario: programme Fall 1999. http://www.bell.ca/filmfest/cinematheque/films/grisbi.htm

Credits: Producers, Robert Dorfmann, Leon Carre ; director, Jacques Becker ; writers, Albert Simonin, Jacques becker, Maurice Griffe ; photography, Pierre Montazel ; music, Jean Wiener ; editor, Marguerite Renoir.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Jeanne Moreau, Lino Ventura, Paul Frankeur, Daniel Cauchy, Rene Dary, Dora Doll, Marilyn Bufferd, Michel Jourdan.

results.title: Voici le Temps des Assassins = a Time for Murder
results.creator_credit: Julien Duvivier, Charles Borderie and Robert Bossis
results.brief_description:
Andre Chatelain is a quiet, middle-aged restaurant owner in Les Halles district of Paris. His life becomes unexpectedly complicated when Catherine pays a visit. She introduces herself as the daughther of his late ex-wife. Moved by the distress of Catherine, Andre invites her to stay with him. Soon after, Gerard, Andre’s adopted son, is smitten by the young woman. But she makes it clear she is only interested in Andre. Andre, however, suspects the young woman to be a liar and possibly a psychotic, mixed up with a number of underworld types. This film offers a very realistic depiction of the life and activities of Les Halles at the time it was considered as the ‘belly of Paris’. The title song is interpreted by Germaine Montero.

Credits: Producers, Charles Borderie, Robert Bossis ; director, Julien Duvivier ; writers, Julien Duvivier, Maurice Bessy, Charles Dorat ; photography, Armand Thirard ; music, Jean Wiener.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Daniele Delorme, Grerad Blain, Germaine Kerjean, Lucienne Bogaert, Robert Arnoux, Jean-Paul Roussillon, Robert Manuel.

results.title: The Man from Snowy River
results.brief_description: The Man From Snowy River, based on the classic Australian poem by Banjo Patterson, tells the story of an 18 year old boy who proves himself a man during an unforgettable chase on horseback down the rugged Snowy Mountains and becomes a legend. The most magnificent footage of horses ever filmed.

constellations_other.name: The ‘Australian' alps
constellations_other.description: These feature films and documentaries show how stories have been told to lay claim - and reclaim - the land and our national identity.

constellations_other.name: Great southern land?
constellations_other.description: Australia is often mythologised in film and TV, but national myths must not only be embraced, but resisted.

results.description: The Man From Snowy River, based on the classic Australian poem by Banjo Patterson, tells the story of an 18 year old boy who proves himself a man during an unforgettable chase on horseback down the rugged Snowy Mountains and becomes a legend. The most magnificent footage of horses ever filmed.

results.title: Emu
results.brief_description: ‘Emu’ is a single-take short film depicting the inquisitive desperation of two emus as they wander through the contemporary urban environment of Broken Hill, NSW. Shot during the 2000s Australian drought, the viewer observes the pace of ‘emu time’ while the two animals are searching for water. An original music score accompanies the footage, created and edited by Sean O’Keeffe.

results.title: Recovering hope
results.brief_description:
‘Recovering Hope’ captures the personal stories of women who fled their homeland Vietnam for a new life in Australia. Sinking boats, pirates and transit camps were experiences for many as they made the dangerous journey.
This Digital Storytelling project, in partnership with VicHealth and Belgium Street Neighbourhood House, marks the 30th anniversary of the first wave of migration.

results.title: The Village green
results.brief_description:
Vietnamese poet Huong Trieu worked with ACMI to produce a visual treatment of her poetry about village life in Vietnam. This was part of a VicHealth funded initiative.
Made at ACMI as part of the ‘Recovering Hope’ Digital Storytelling project, in partnership with VicHealth and Belgium Street Neighbourhood House.
